bibl.title: Report to William Crawford Gorgas by Henry Rose Carter, August 28, 1907

div1.p: Carter's report on pneumonia in the Canal Zone concludes that pneumonia is prevalent among recent arrivals who have contracted infectious catarrh. He recommends that prevention efforts concentrate on better medical treatment of catarrh and ensuring that new men have blankets.

div1.head: Report to William Crawford Gorgas by Henry Rose Carter, August 28, 1907
div1.p:
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
CANAL ZONE
OFFICE OF DIRECTOR OF HOSPITALS
Ancon, C.Z. August 28th, 1907. (Rewritten Sept. 7th, 1907.)
Colonel W. C. Gorgas,
Chief Sanitary Officer,
Ancon, Canal Zone.
Sir:

The Board called by your Order of April 11th, 1907, G. O. #20,
amended letter April 13th, copies enclosed, to investigate the matter of the
prevalence of pneumonia on the Canal Zone and have the honor to submit the
following report:

At the time this Board was called, pneumonia was widely prevalent
over the Canal Zone, existing at practically every district therein, but
varying very much as to the degree of its prevalence. For instance, in the
preceding month, Tabernilla, with a population of not less than 700 colored,
gave 31 cases; La Boca, with a population of over 800, gave one case. It
was practically confined to the colored population.

Pneumonia began to show permanently in the morbidity and mortality
statistics of the Isthmus about 15 months before and had almost from the
beginning been most widely and most unequally diffused.

It was determined:
(A) To inspect the places where phenmonia was most prevalent, Taber-
nilla and Gorgona Encampment; making a comparison between the houses where cases,
c 2
one or more than one had occurred, and the houses as close as possible, where
no cases had occurred, to determine if there was any difference in the conditions
of the houses themselves which could account for pneumonia developing in the one
and not doing so in the other.
(B) To inspect the localities; comparing the houses and their environ-
ments in stations where pneumonia was especially prevalent, with the conditions at
stations where it was least prevalent to see if the conditions under which they
were occupied, or in their environments could explain the differences of the
prevalence of pneumonia in the different districts.
(C) To make an examination of the clinical records of pneumonia cases.
(D) To examine the records of pathological findings of pneumonia cases
of the Ancon Hospital. The first two inquiries, (A) and (B), were to be conducted
as far as possible by the full Board, or by as many members as possible, acting
together; the third (C) by the Director of Hospitals; the fourth (D) by the
Director of Labratory.

The causes which might influence the prevalence of pneumonia and the
were
existence of each, where therefore made with the subject of this inquiry as follows:
1. Overcrowding or lack of ventilation.
2. Exposure to draft, i. e. inrregular or excessive ventilation.
3. Lack of sufficient bed covering.
4. Altitude; low lying places having wet grounds and being damp; high
places having greater change of temperature between day and night.
5. The time of the year, wet or dry season.
6. Prevalence of malaria.
7. House infection; i. e. spreading from case to case in the same quarters.
8. Acclimatization, or length of residence on the Isthmus.

This last was taken up, (1) because upon even superficial examin-
3
ation of the statistics, it seemed apparent that an unduly large proportion were
among those who had newly arrived, and (2) on account of an observation of
Dr. Darling made in July of last year, in which he predicated that pneumonia in
most instances was preceded by an influenza. Obviously such an influenzea, which has
been prevalent on the Isthmus for approximately two years, although by no means
confined to the newly arrived, would be most general among them, and therefore
accepting this observation as correct, pneumonia would be likewise. The patholog-
ical record was especially to be examined with reference to the existence of in-
flamation of the accessory sinuses in patients dead of pneumonia -- as per the
report mentioned -- with control observations of sinusites in cases dead of other
diseases.

The infspection of the houses at Gorgona Encampment and Tabernilla, where
the pneumonia was most prevalent, revealed no differences in regard to crowding,
ventilation, cleanliness or amount of bed covering in the houses that had furnished
no cases, from those in which cases, one or more than one, had developed.
The result of this inquiry was absolutely negative.

A comparison of scamps like those above named with those at La Boca and
Gatun, both in low ground like Tabernilla, and Pedro Miguel; Paraiso, and Carthagenta,
all in high ground like the Encampment, revealed no differences in the above points,
excepting a larger amount of bed covering. The camps at La Boca, the most crowded,
furnished practically no cases of pneumonia. The camps at Paraiso and Carthagenta,
the least crowded, furnished also an extremely small number of cases. If anything,
the camps at Tabernilla were in the best condition as regards cleanliness and general
police, of any examined. The men in these camps, La Boca, Paraiso, Pedro Miguel and
Carthagenta stated that they were “old men,” that is they had been on the Isthmus for
4
a considerable length of time. About forty or fifty were asked this question and
all had been on the Isthmus a considerable time, not less than six or eight months;
most of them claiming a year or more. The result of this examination was also nega-
tive.

The examination of these places and houses was made with a considerable
amount of pains and involved considerable work and time. I enclose a few samples
of the records of the examinations made of the houses for the above investigations.

From the Specimen Record submitted herewith it is obvious that some of this
data has to be obtained from the patient himself, it being simply impossible for
the small number of District Physicians to make the personal examination
for all the data that is required of each patient. It will be seen later that some of this data is
unreliable.

From the data collected, the accompanying analyses are submitted and
the following conclusions drawn:
(1) Time of Year. Exhibit A.
It will be seen that the pneymonia increased from the beginning of the
dry season, being greatest towards its end; 124 cases in April, the driest month.
Dropping down some in May and June, which are wetter months, but raising again in
July, which was about as wet as June. It evidently was decidedly worse in the last
dry season than in the wet season so far, July 31st. This is opposed to its general
course last year. There was an increase of about ten or fifteen percent in the number
of colored employees from January 1st to June 1st. Very few colored men arrived (and
a number left) in October and November of 1906. The heavy importation of colored
contract laborers began about January 14th and ceased May 16th, 1907. We do not
find, then, any relation to season or time of year.
5
(2) Locality. Ex. B.
This table shows a great difference in the prevalence of pneumonia
at different localities, but gives no light as to the cause of such differences.

150 cases per 1000 at Tabernilla with 30 at Christobal and 24 at La Boca, where the
ground was equally low and approximately the same climatic conditions prevailing,
except such as might be due to the presence of salt air. Gatun but little higher
than Tabernilla gives 20 cases per thousand, and is in the same fresh water dis-
trict. The Gorgona Encampment, an elevated place, gives a high percentage, while
Cascadas, at near the same altitude and as far as one can tell, the same climatic
conditions, gives the lowest on the list.

Gatun, Pedro Miguel and Tabernilla during this time were giving the
largest percentage of malaria of any places on the zone. They gave 20, 20 and 150 per thousand cases
of pneumonia respectively. There seems to be no relation then to altitude or
prevalence of malaria.
HOUSE INFECTION. Ex. C.

Of 205 houses identified as those in which pneumonia had occurred,
in only 26 did more than a single case occur. There is no evidence then that it
is spread by house infection.

Here we rely entirely upon the statement of the patients and we think
little reliance can be placed in their statements upon this subject, as we find
they call everything a blanket from a strip of cotton cloth to a gunny sack.

This exhibit would show that more than two-thirds of the cases had
bed covering. As an examination of the camps where pneumonia was most prevalent,
did not show a blanket in more than one bunk in three, this exhibit if it could be
-6-
relied on would tend to show that the presence of bed covering induced to pneumonia.

(1) Balancing this against (1) the fact that the barracks where pneumonia
were most prevalent showed decidedly less bed covering than in the places where
pneumonia was less prevalent, and (2) the general experience elsewhere in the
disease, we think no deductions should be drawn from this exhibit, and this table
should be disregarded.

p.hi: DEFICIENT VENTILATION AND EXPOSURE TO DRAFT. Ex. E.

div1.p:
It was attempted to get data on this by finding out if the patient had
slept in the top bunk or not. This inquiry was not begun at the beginning and is,
therefore, less extensive than is desirable. It is believed, however, to be fairly
accurate becasue, while very generally the patient did not know the number of his
house, yet, he seemed always to know whether he slept in the top bunk or not, and
this seems reasonable.

The barracks are built with a louvre about three feet high, just under
the eaves and just slightly above the top bunks, which run along the sides parallel
and close to these louvres. It is obvious then that the men occupying the top
bunks have (1) better ventilation and (2) are more exposed to draft than those
occupying the other bunks. Obviously also there being three tiers of bunks one-
third of the total number are top bunks. In point of fact less than one-third of
the number in barracks sleep in the top bunks, because if the barrack is not en-
tirely full (which, however, is not usually the case) the top bunk is empty as
it requires more climbing to get to it than the others. If, then, lack of venti-
lation has been a predisposing cause, there should be decidedly less than one-third
of the total number of cases of pneumonia in the top bunk. If, however, exposure
to draft has not been such a cause, there should be over one-third of the top bunk men
men in the pneumonia list of top bunk men of the bunk men. In point of fact the ratio - 52 to 162 - is slightly
7
under one-third, about the ratio of the men occupying the top bunk to the whole
number. This subject, then, does not show that deficient ventilation due to
sleeping in the lower bunks, or exposure to draft due to sleeping in the top
bunks, in any wise affected the prevalence of pneumonia.

p.hi:
Ex. E and F
Close or Open Quarters.

div1.p: No deductions will be drawn as the data is regarded as utterly unreliable.

Similarly no deduction is drawn from Ex. G, as the data collected is not
sufficient. This data, however, is believed to be reliable, and as far as it goes
gives a negative finding; i. e. bunk most exposed to the draft when the door is
opened did not affect the percentage of pneumonia.
This exhibit shows:

(1) The number of “new men” (men not over three months on the Isthmus) and
“old men” (men over three months on the Isthmus) among the colored employes of the
Commission at the commencement of each month, - also the number of cases of pneumonia
in each of the above classes during each month, with the ratio of the number of “new
men” to the number of “old men” on the pay-roll and the number of cases among the
“new” to the number of cases to the “old men” and the ratio of these ratios. Ob-
viously if both classes of men in the above are equally liable to pneumonia, the
ratio of the ratios should be 1; if the “old men” are more liable to pneumonia the
ratio should be less than 1; if on the other hand, the “new men” are more liable,
the ratio should be greater than 1.

An examination of this exhibit shows that in every month the ratio is
greater than 1, decidedly so.

The conclusions to be drawn from the exhibit are that residence on the
8
Isthmus for over three months does give a decided protection against pneumonia.
This is the only positive finding given by this investigation, i. e. examination
of the clinical records.

There are several differential conditions between the “old” and the
“new” men which may be factors.
(1) The newly arrived man does not know how to care for himself so well
as the older resident. The complete change in his life and habits must, to some
extent, have a perturbating effect on his health, and thus would be apt to pre-
dispose to any kind of disease prevailing.
(2) He is also a blanketless man. The examination of the camps show
generally a much larger proportion of blankets, and other bed covering, in the
camps of the older residents than in those of the newly arrived.
(3) There is, and for nearly two years has been, prevailing on the Isthmus
an infectious catarrhl inflammation of the respiratory tract, especially the upper
part of it. This occurs, we suppose recurs, among a certain proportion of the older
residents, but it is extremely prevalent among the newly arrived men. This has
been noted by all the District Physicians for the past 18 or 20 months and was to
be expected; as such a disease would naturally produce a temporary immunity.
All of the above may well be factors.

p.hi: (D) EXAMINATION OF RECORD OF PATHOLOGICAL FINDINGS OF PNEUMONIA CASES.

div1.p:
Attention is now invited to the accompanying paper from the Director of
the Labratory (Ex. I), which shows (1) that there is a large number of purulent
sinusites -- a condition which in the United States would usually be considered the
result of a recent Influenza -- among the autopsies of colored patients dead from
other than pneumococcus infection -- 17%. (2) That among autopsies of patients dead
9
of Pneumococcus infection the proportion of such sinusites is very much larger -- 61%.
these sinusites being pneumococcus infections.

There is, thus, good evidence of a connection between the purulent pneumococcus
sinusites and the pneumococcus infection of other organs, either (a) directly casual,
or (b) both the result of a common cause. His statement of July, 1906 that the age
of the sinus infection “is appreciably greater than that of the lung or meningeal
lesion” is to be noted and would naturally lead to his conclusion in the last para-
graph that “the portal of entry of the Pneumococcus is in most instances an inflamed
accessory nasal sinus the mucuous membrane of which is fitted for the reception of
the pneumococcus by an antecedent influenze or rhinitis.”

Dr. Darling states verbally that in the autopsies of those dead of
pneumococcus infection that there were also a considerable number of pneumococcus
inflamations of the sinuses not purulent. The ratio of pneumococcus sinusites,
purulent and nonpurulent, in autopsies of those dead of pneumonia infection is
then decidedly greater than 61%.

There is no reason why such a sinus, inflamed but not purulent, should
not be an antrum of entrance for the organism, as well as a purulent one, and the
probability of some such casual relation between them, direct or indirect, is very
great and to your Board convincing.

Correlating the findings of the Pathelogist with the one positive conclu-
sion reached by examination of the clinical record, i. e. that the newly arrived men
are far more susceptible to pneumonia than the older residents, we believe this in-
creased susceptibility is due mainly to the greater prevalence of this infections
catarrh (influenza) among the newly arrived, although this would naturally be ac-
centuated by the other two factors mentioned on page No. 8 -- lack of blankets and
ignorance of caring for themselves. With this correlation this opinion is so
10
strongly confirmed that we accept the role of the prevailing infectious catarrh
of the upper respiratory tract as the prime factor in predisposing to pneumonia
(Pneumococcus infection) predicated by Dr. Darling in his report of July 1906
unreservedly.

To sum up your Board cannot find that the prevalence of Pneumonia is
affected by:
(1) The time of year.
(2) The altitude. Tabernilla - about 12' above sea level and abso-
lutely flat, and Gorgona Encampment, about 105' high and well drained, gave the
highest proportion of cases, while Cristobal, La Boca and Corozal, all comparable
with the first, and Las Cascadas, Pedro Miguel and Paraiso, comparable with the
second, gave low percentages.
(3) The prevalence of Malaria.
(4) House infection - by previous case.
(5) Deficient ventilation and over-crowding, as they exist in
Commission Quarters.
(6) Exposure to draft - as it exists in Commission Quarters.

That it is decidedly more prevalent in men newly arrived -- under three
months -- than in older residents. 4 1/2 times as prevalent

That it is mainly due to the presence on the Isthmus of an infectious
catarrh, which naturally is especially prevalent among the new arrivals, and which
predisposes them to pneumonia.

That the process is generally the production of an inflamation of the
accessory sinuses -- due to the catarrh -- the muccus membrane of which is thus
fitted for the reception and growth of the pneumococcus, and this serves as the
atrium of entrance for that organism.

Since we can do nothing to prevent the employe contracting this catarrh
we must do what is possible to render its course, and hence its effects milder:
(1) That the role of the infectious catarrh prevalent on the Isthmus
in the cauzation of pneumonia be clearly recognized, and that therefore it be
treated by the District Physicians with that knowledge before them and considered
as a graver disease than it has hitherto been.
(2) That as far as possible the newly arrived colored laborers be
grouped at places where Drying Houses are located, so that clothes and bedding
may be rapidly dried.
Indeed the general introduction of Drying Houses would, we believe,
render the catarrhal symptoms of this infection less severe, and therefore less
likely to lead to pneumonia.
(3) That a blanket and a piece of matting or canvas, or two blankets
be issued to the colored man on his arrival, unless he has sufficient bed covering,
and charged to his account.

Two coverings are advised because it is advisable to put some fabric
between the cloth of the bunk and the man. The piece of matting is better (warmer)
than the canvas, and has been used to cover canvas cots with great advantage by the
Hospital Division. Naturally either is cheaper, and less good, than a second blanket.

No loss will be caused to the laborer by making him take a blanket. In
general he buys one about the third or fourth month, paying more for it than he would
for one from the Commissary, and which he would have at the most critical time, for
him, on the Isthmus.

A few bunks have bottoms of metal strips, and no cloth. These especially
ought to be covered by some non-conducting fabric.

H. R. CARTER
Chairman of Board.

E X H I B I T I.

From a large series of autopsies in which a purulent sinusitis only was
noted, there was the following association.

Catarrhal sinusitis is of frequent occurrence at all autopsies. Pneumoc-
occi and a few pus cells are found in smears from the catarrhal exudate.

There have been 44 cases of orchitis or epididymitis for which the opera-
tion of castration was performed. Three of these cases presenting typical exudate were
examined for pneumococci by cultivation and animal inoculation with positive result.
R E P O R T O F A N C O N H O S P I T A L.
July 1906.

The pathologist of Ancon Hospital reports the following deductions from
investigations of cases of pneumococcus infection:

"Having noticed for some time a coincident inflammation of the accessary
nasal sinuses with acute cerebro-spinal pneumococcus meningitis, it occurred to me
to investigate the relation of these sinuses to pneumococcus infections.

"Up to July 21, 1906, the accessary nasal sinuses had been examined
with regard to this point in 52 autopsies, 37 of which were pneumococcus infections
as follows: Lobar pneumonia 22, acute pericarditis 1, acute meningitis 9, septicaemia
5, remaining 15 were controls. It is found that 92 per cent of all pneumococcus
infections coming to autopsy show to a very marked degree more or less typical
pneumococcus inflammation of one or more of the accessary nasal sinuses.
The inflammation is generally intense; it is fibrino purulent in character,
fibrin and mononuclear cells being abundant. Pneumococci are always present
and in number depending upon the duration of the process.

"A point of great importance is the age of the sinus affection, which
is appreciable greater than that of the lung or meningeal lesion.

"Ninety-one per cent of the pneumonia cases showed a sinusitis. One
hundred per cent of the cases of simple meningitis presented an inflammation of
one or more of the sinuses, and in every one the middle ears and mastoid cells
were normal.

"The case of ‘primary’ pneumococcus pericarditis is of interest because
all the sinuses were involved, yet the meninges were normal, and the lungs contained
only small patches of broncho-pneumonia.

"In the pneumococcus septicaemia group 80 per cent were found to be
associated with a sinusitis. The controls were all other than pneumococcus infec-
tions just as they came to autopsy, and of these 20 per cent had an acute inflamma-
tion of at least one of the sinuses.

"It has been observed that acute sinusitis of the maxillary, sphenoidal
and frontal sinuses, and acute ethmoiditis of the posterior ethmoidal cells is
common among negro laborers of recent (one to five months) arrival from Barbadoes
and the smaller islands. The fatal pneumococcus infections similarly are among
that class.

"It is thought that the portal of entry of the pneymococcus is in most
instances an inflamed accessary nasal sinus, the mucous membrane of which is fitted
for the reception of the pneumococcus by an antecedent influenza or rhinitis.
